text:
She slipped off last week to get married without a word of warning to the public. Now Meghan McCain is sharing the details of her romantic wedding to conservative writer Ben Domenech.

Returning to The View on Monday morning, the co-host spilled the beans about her country-themed big day.

She said: “Me and now my husband (which is so weird, to say I have a husband), Ben, we got married at our ranch in Sedona.

“It was real country. Like I wanted a western country wedding.”

Meghan McCain revealed the details of her country-themed wedding to husband Ben Domenech. (Credit: Instagram/@meghanmccain)

Read more: ‘The View' Star Shuns Wedding Gifts, Asks for This Instead

Looking at pictures from the day, the 33-year-old said: “My aisle was cowhide. John Dickerson from Face the Nation married us.”

The newlywed said outlaw country performer Shooter Jennings sang during the Nov. 21 event, as well as former American Idol star Clay Aiken.

The daughter of Senator John McCain said: “I pulled Clay Aiken out of retirement to sing and got my dad to cry, because he sang a beautiful song for us.

“And I got very drunk on whiskey and had a great time dancing the entire time.”

Meghan and Ben at their wedding sitting alongside fellow conservative S.E. Cupp. (Credit: Instagram/@secupp)

Meghan – who kept her relationship and engagement with Ben under the radar – said: “It was really fun. I think we overdo it with weddings in general and talking about it.

“I understand why people do it. It's a beautiful celebration of love and the meaningful experience of doing it in front of your friends and family,” she said.

Meghan and Ben’s wedding comes at a sad time for the former Fox News host because her father is currently battling stage 4 brain cancer.

Meghan spoke about getting married following her father Senator John McCain's cancer diagnosis. (Credit: Instagram/@meghanmccain)

Read more: 'GMA' Co-Host Says 'Mean Viewer' Made Her Consider Changing Jobs

She said: “Before [President] Trump and before my dad's cancer and before all these things, I feel like the first…year and a half of our relationship was so fun.

“Just having a good time.”

But, she added: “The second's been really, really, really, really hard.

“And so there's something about celebrating love in a time of sadness as well that was probably more meaningful had it been an easier time.”

But when co-host Joy Behar asked Meghan if the relationship feels different now that they’re married, the Republican said: “No, not at all.

“We came back to New York, had tomato soup and watched Homeland…last night.”
title: Meghan McCain Dishes on Her Wedding – Tears, Booze and Country Music!
